awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Cellulose Based Material Innovations for Ocean Compostable Fish Friendly Plastic Packaging Replacement Platform Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this STTR project is advancing the development of environmentally safe packaging. The global packaging market has been estimated to grow to $980 B in 2022, with lids estimated at $1.4 B in 2020. As 40% of plastic is created for one-time-use, a need exists for innovative packaging. The current petroleum plastic lids are not sustainable nor recycled and they do not break down in the environment. The proposed solution is a new class of hot and cold drink lids that are low-cost, can be recycled with paper, and will not harm the ocean environment if littered. 

This STTR Phase I project proposes to advance the translation of a method to use highly refined wood cellulose microfibers, combined with calcium carbonate and other low-cost additives, to generate a lid that mimics the feel of current plastic polypropylene and polystyrene lids but provides excellent environmental performance. The environmental impact will be tested via decomposition time, and ocean impact by zebrafish embryo exposure effects and mortality.  The proposed solution will demonstrate environmental decomposing behavior not obtained with any petroleum or corn plastic material. The technical hurdles include molding and drying this new pulp into an automated lid production process at scale. This project will characterize this new pulp.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
It is widely known that single use plastic is producing waste that is harmful to the ocean. This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project supported Paramount Planet Product (P3RD)'s investigation into the production material for a novel class of drink lids. This material can be recycled with paper, will break down in the environment, and if littered will not harm the ocean. They are cost competitive and feel like plastic.

This material have the potential to replace the polypropylene and polystyrene in single use to-go containers that are common in today's market. The current petroleum plastic and bio-plastics are not easily recycled, and do not break down in the environment without extra heat and specialized equipment. The novel aspect of this work is to use highly refined wood cellulose microfibers, combined with calcium carbonate and other additives, to generate a lid that would mimic the current plastic lid, but have excellent environmental performance.

Initial samples that have been produced are quite similar to plastic and resist water for the short term, but when soaked in water do weaken and break down. This new material functions without the use of toxic ‘forever’ Polyfluoroalkyl  substances (PFAS) chemical resins. Fibrillated Cellulose (FC) has been long touted as an environmentally friendly material that could theoretically be used in packaging material. Technical hurdles have prevented its widespread use in the industry. This Phase I has generated solutions to these technical challenges and has shown great promise in current manufacturing settings. This creates the potential to revitalize the pulp and paper industry making American made products utilizing USA grown tree based materials.

A techno-economic analysis was produced as part of the Phase I research. It showed pricing comparable to existing products that are on the market today. The decomposing behavior shown by this new product is not obtained with any current petroleum plastic material or Polylactic Acid (PLA) bioplastics. By testing zebrafish embryo development and mortality, this new material was also investigated for the environmental impact it might have on aquatic life. This is guiding our design of a packaging product that is environmentally benign. P3RD's new packaging material that will withstand legislation of plastic bans protecting the environment.

The research from Phase I shows this new material has the potential to create more US manufacturing opportunities. In making new circular designed products we are reviving a heritage pulp and paper industry in the United States. This pulp and paper industry has suffered because of a lack of product innovation compiled with overseas competition. The goal is to have American made tree based material production be able to displace current plastic and fiber lids made in China or other foreign nations.

To go packaging is a growing market. According to an October 2020 report from 360 Research Reports, the global disposable tableware market is projected to reach US $32,820 million by 2026. This is up from US$29,320 million in 2020, at a CAGR of 1.9%. Green packaging products are growing even higher rate with a 6.8% CAGR during 2021-2026.

Paramount Planet Product sees these new market trends, and new customer demands for cellulose based packaging as a time to ignite growth in the US pulp and paper industry. Our molded pulp fiber research is utilizing USA grown plant based materials. It can function without the use of toxic ‘forever’ chemical resins. A techno economic analysis produced as part of the Phase I research showed pricing comparable to existing products that are on the market today. This will result in an alternative to the current single use plastic packaging. It naturally biodegrades and is shown to be safe for developing zebrafish embryos, which are a long standing proxy for environmental and organism health. Our research will allow the packaging and restaurant industries to grow without damaging the environment.

 


Last Modified: 08/07/2021
Modified by: Ariadne Dimoula

Images (1 of )
  • Paramount Planet Product founding members Ariadne Dimoula and Claudia Lowd are working with partners at the University of Maine Process Development Center (UMaine PDC) to create Ocean Compostable Fish Friendly packaging materials.
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Ariadne and Claudia at UMaine's PDC
  • Zebrafish at the University of Dartmouth, Massachusetts are shown swimming around. While still embryos, we watched these fish develop in order to test Ocean Compostable Fish Friendly packaging material.
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Zebrafish in tank
  • This P3RD material sample is an example of the tree-based Ocean Compostable Fish Friendly packaging material that we are creating. In this photo it is about to be dissolved and tested with zebrafish embryos at the University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth Bioengineering Laboratory.
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Material being tested
  • Claudia Lowd of P3RD and Dr. Mohammed Algharrawi of the University of Maine are pictured working with new aluminum mold and newly created lid product samples at the University of Maine's Process Development Center (PDC)
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Aluminum mold and sample examination at PDC
  • Lenzing Instrument Slosh Box 100 is used in this experiment to move the materials in a saltwater ocean-replicant condition. The material in the 3 bays have been treated for 24 hours to different conditions such as heater, room temperature and freezer.
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Testing Compostability of Materials in Marine-like Condition
  • Paramount Planet Product (P3RD)'s Ariadne Dimoula and Claudia Lowd are shown looking through a stereoscopic microscope to research heartbeat rates of developing zebrafish embryos leading to the creation of an Ocean Compostable Fish Friendly testing methodology.
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Zebrafish Embryo Development Research
  • Paramount Planet Product (P3RD)'s Ariadne Dimoula and Claudia Lowd are shown looking through a stereoscopic microscope to research heartbeat rates of developing zebrafish embryos leading to the creation of an Ocean Compostable Fish Friendly testing methodology.
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Ariadne Dimoula
    Zebrafish Embryo Development Research
